document_title: Kidney failure: Causes, signs, diagnosis and treatment
subsection_content:
The disease can be the result of a number of health problems, and determining the cause is helpful in helping to identify the type of kidney failure. The cause of the disease can come from some of the following factors:
Reduced blood flow to the kidneys
A sudden loss of blood flow to the kidneys will likely lead to kidney failure. This condition is often due to causes such as: heart disease, liver scarring or liver failure, severe burns, allergic reactions, severe infections such as sepsis, etc. Use of high blood pressure and anti-inflammatory drugs can also occur. can limit blood flow to the kidneys.
Urine excretion problem
When the body cannot eliminate urine, toxins will accumulate and overload the kidneys. Causes of this condition include some cancers in the colon, bladder, prostate (in men), cervix (in women)...
Other conditions that can interfere with urination and over time lead to kidney failure such as: kidney stones, prostate enlargement, blood clots in the urinary tract, damage to the nerves that control the bladder, etc.
Other causes
Some other causes that can lead to kidney failure include:
Blood clots appear in or around the kidney; Infection; Heavy metal poisoning; Vasculitis; Lupus; Glomerulonephritis; Hemolytic uremic syndrome; Multiple myeloma; Scleroderma; Hemorrhage causes thrombotic thrombocytopenia; Medicines to treat cancer and some autoimmune diseases; Dye used in diagnostic imaging; Some antibiotics; Uncontrolled diabetes; Kidney aging due to age (this is one of the main causes of kidney failure in the elderly)
